did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.physdesc: Publications, correspondence, photographs, printed material, reports, manuscripts.
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Collection consists of papers related to Christopherson's research, writing, and teaching.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Susan Christopherson was an economic geographer and Professor and Chair in the Department of City and Regional Planning at Cornell University. Born in St. Paul, Minnesota in 1947, she earned a Bachelor's in Urban Studies and a Master's degree in Geography from the University of Minnesota in 1972 and 1975. After receiving a doctorate in 1983 from the University of California, Berkeley, she was a research associate at the University of California, Los Angeles Graduate School of Architecture and Urban Planning and the Center for U.S.-Mexican Studies at the University of California, San Diego; a visiting professor of geography at San Diego State University; and a visiting lecturer at the University of Texas, El Paso. In 1987, Christopherson joined Cornell's faculty, where she was the first woman promoted to full professor in the Department of City and Regional Planning and, in 2014, became the first woman appointed Chair. Her research and teaching focused on economic development, urban labor markets, and location patterns in media and other service industries. She completed studies on advanced manufacturing in New York's Southern Tier, the photonics industry in Rochester, the role of universities and colleges in revitalizing the upstate New York economy, and production trends affecting media industries in New York City. She also focused on human-environment relations and public policy related to unconventional energy extraction and nontraditional energy sources, analyzing the safety of crude oil transport by rail and the economic consequences of Marcellus shale natural gas drilling. Christopherson co-authored "Remaking Regional Economies: Power, Labor and Firm Strategies in the Knowledge Economy," winner of the 2009 Regional Studies Association Best Book Award, and she published more than 100 articles and policy reports, served on the editorial boards of several leading journals, and was editor-in-chief of a Regional Studies Association book series on cities and regions. At Cornell, she was a faculty fellow in the David R. Atkinson Center for a Sustainable Future. She also consulted with the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and the United Nations, and she served on a National Research Council panel considering the implications of shale gas and oil development for communities in New York and Pennsylvania. In 2015, she was given a Lifetime Achievement Award by the American Association of Geographers. Christopherson died in 2016.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of papers related to Christopherson's research, writing, and teaching.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions:
accessrestrict.p: Access to folders 38 and 40 in box 2, folder 9 in box 4, folders 32 and 54 in box 6 and folder 7, 36 and 51 in box 19 restricted to the permission of the office of origin.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use:
userestrict.p: Due to the fragility and potential degradation of moving image and sound recordings, viewing and listening is limited to items that have been digitized. If an item is in another media format, you may request to have the item digitized for access. Information on ordering access copies may be found on our Reproductions & Permissions page.

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Susan Christopherson papers, #15-2-4300. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

From file box labeled: Wal-Mart (boxed 1/07)--Three pieces of correspondence from Stanley Brunn, who was editing a book entitled 'Wal-Mart World,' in which SMC would have a chapter entitled "The Myth of Wal-Martization: Retail Globalization and Local Competition in Japan and Germany"
From file box labeled: Wal-Mart (boxed 1/07)--Draft of a paper comparing Wal-Mart and IKEA , written with Nathan Lillie

From file box labeled: Wal-Mart (boxed 1/07)--June 2003 version of a paper/talk originally completed in September, 2001, to be presented at Laboratorio de Anlisis Institucional del Sistema Universitario Mexicano Universidad Autnoma Metropolitana (lecture noted here: http://laisumedu.org/DESIN_Ibarra/salon/Walmartizacion.htm; paper on-line at http://laisumedu.org/DESIN_Ibarra/salon/si2/wm-29.pdf).
From file box labeled: Wal-Mart (boxed 1/07)--Notes relating to the Wal-Mart paper she was writing, as well as thoughts on others' work and a couple of short notes from Neil Wrigley.
From file box labeled: Wal-Mart (boxed 1/07)--Material related to the paper for Stan Brunn's edited book
From file box labeled: Wal-Mart (boxed 1/07)--Notes relating to the Wal-Mart paper she was writing
A couple of articles about rural economies plus the appendix to a report (draft) by Arch Dotson, Bob Roe, and SMC (dated 1/19/00) entitled "The Danby Economy"

Materials relating to a UN Conference on Trade and Development meeting at which SMC presented--includes a report entitled "Jordan's Policies and Strategies in Audiovisual Media' that is dated April 30, 2000, written by SMC
Includes a set of notes plus two newsletters
Contains proposals for British research projects and an article (with SMC comments) she was asked to review for Economic Geography
Invitation and materials related to a conference on the future viability of the arts at Ohio State

Materials relating to a presentation at the Association of Collegiate Schools of Planning meetings in 2002, including paper and transparencies for a paper entitled "School Finance and Income Inequality - Lessons from New York State," on which SMC is first author and Remington Stone is second.

Contains transparencies and 6-page handwritten outline of a talk "Are Quality and Equality Incompatible? The Foundations of Continued Inequality in California School Finance" given at the Public Policy Institute of California. Also contains manuscript for a book review of Dreier, et al.'s book, 'Place Matters.'

Includes various materials related to cultural economy approach, notably a program and notes (both for her talk and about others' talks) from the Art, Culture and the Changing Economy a 2002 conference at which SMC appeared on a panel with Richard Florida

A letter to Katherine McFate at the Rockefeller Foundation in response to a note that seemingly asks SMC if she would like support for her project
Materials relating to the CRP 635 Workshop on State Economic Development Practices--contains a short piece by SMC on clusters and economic development

Materials tied to project with Rolf Pendall on demographic and econoic changes in Upstate NY, includes reports for Brookings, slides from a talk by SMC and RP, coverage in a CRP publication. Worth noting at the end of the slides is the summary of publicity the project has received.
Contains Sponsored Programs Internal Academic Approval form and note to Holly Ladue regarding a study that used no sources and made questionable claims
Contains various source material for project w/some annotations etc.
Folder with charts, a letter from Mike Asher who is editing a book (Contracting Out Hollywood) in which SMC has a chapter, and related materials
Stories about Canadian media industries
Notes and a draft of 'Divide and Conquor,' the essay that would be published in 'Contracting Out Hollywood.'

Materials related to the study of Hollywood and the film industry, including handwritten notes that say "USE for Media Book," although it is unclear if they are for the Divide and Conquor essay or for her own, unpublished, media book.
Draft of biographical data, project schedule, etc. from a proposal for research on, I believe, food workers with Ned Rightor. Linda Nessel's bio is crossed out from one draft.
Notes entitled "Deliberative Democracy for Intro," related to Hydraulic Fracturing Project
Notes and edited slide print outs and related materials for a talk on hydraulic fracturing
Materials and notes relating to a draft book chapter for a project on hydraulic fracturing involving Madelon Finkel

Newspaper with photo of anti-drilling protesters in Pennsylvania
Report on crude oil transport from Congress along with SMC note regarding JPER articles
Notes toward an introduction to a book(?) on hydraulic fracturing some handwritten, some typed
Articles relating to gas-related NIMBYism (Not in my back yard-ism)
Notes relating to interview plan and related articles
Annotated report entitled "Preliminary Report on Arrest/Offense Data and Drilling Activity in Major US Shale Play

did.unittitle: Empire State Survey: Notes for Commuity Study

scopecontent.p: Results from 2012 Empire State Poll on natural gas drilling, notes on how to summarize the results, and a sheet of notes entitled 'Susan Arbetter'

Notes and two syllabi from Nichola Lowe for economic development courses
Articles and an anonymous essay marked "for Lumina review"
Notes and materials for a presentation in Boston related to the creative economy in small cities, with reference to institutions of higher education

Notes and related materials

Edited draft of a paper entitled "Why Universities Won't Save Us: The Limits to "the Learning Region" as a Formula for Sustainable Regional Economies" and related materials
Assorted clippings related to energy transitions, some with notes
Four pages of notes on a range of topics, one headed "Question to answer: What does state-centric network mean for energy transitions? Movement from one form to another or lock in?"
Includes radio host Susan Arbetter-related materials NRC Workshop notes-correspondence with Jacob McNally, reaction to Broome County plan, notes on New Headwater's Study, etc.
Four pages of notes on citizen science and new forms of expertise in energy, which appears to have been a possible comparative project
Three pages of notes on a panel about education spending in NY State

Contains notes on the proposal for a book about shale gas that was submitted to the University of North Carolina Press by SMC and Ned Rightor. There are many versions of reaction to the reviews as well as correspondence with their editor, Joseph Parsons, a draft contract with comments, a later memo on how the book is evolving from a primer to a set of essays, and related materials.
Various short notes and a few popular press articles

Notes, chapter synopsis, a memo about next steps, and other materials for SMC and Ned Rightor's book on insentives. Despite folder title, there are also some hand-written notes about the second chapter of the book as well.
Contains only an e-mail from Christopher Smith about trends in non-employer establishments during the 2000s in the film industry
A variety of reports related to energy as well as correspondence with new research assistant Sam Scoppettone
Notes and memos related to Heinz-funded research on economic impact of fracking and possibility of tourism as alternative local economic development strategy; Includes a budget with SMC salary noted
Data, charts, and other materials, including meeting notes, memos, and completed proposal to Heinz
A memo requesting the final Heinz report and SMC's cover page for the final report

Notes and a preliminary paper (3 days before the 12/14/2013 presentation) for a talk at a workshop on financialization of Society at Trinity College, Dublin. The talk is called "How Does Financialization Affrect Manufacturing Investment? Preliminary Evidence for the US and UK"
Correspondence related to an invited paper that was to be written for the 6th GUNi World Report in Higher Education. The paper was not published. Also contains notes for the "Erkner talk"
Notes and related materials for a talk SMC gave at the second Global Value Chains in Europe Network two-day workshop entitled "Bariers to Re-shoring Manufacturing"
Notes for a paper on manufacturing that was intended for Policy Journal
A few notes, clearly not the central repository of work on this topic.
A few notes about changes in corporate attitudes regarding their obligations to regions

Many notes and related materials for the regions book (with Jennifer Clark), including a series description of David Angel's series for Routledge. Notes related to article including correspondence with Jennifer Clark (then at Cornell)
Contains note cards detailing some U.S. firms working in Germany along with the sources of that information

did.unittitle: U.S. Firms in Germany: Sources Articles

scopecontent.p: Contain materials related to companies in Germany

Contains notes and a paper entitled Complicating Assumptions: Rules as Resources in Anglo-American and German Investment Decisions that was presented at a conference on European integration in Berlin, July 22-25, 1993
A 1991 version and 1993 draft paper with edits entitled The Path to Fragmented Bargaining Power: Industrial Relations in Entertainment Media

A proposal for the U.S. Department of Agriculture to document efforts among economic development agencies that promote "alternatives to inter-juridictional competition among state and local officials"

Notes for a book with English geographer Linda McDowell, along series description/proposal for “Reshaping Human Geography: A Major New Introductory Series,” edited by Stuart Corbridge, Ron Martin and Linda McDowell. Within the series proposal there are seven books described, only two of which have authors assigned. One is ‘Work, Welfare, and Community,’ to be authored by Susan Christopherson and Linda McDowell. There’s a one paragraph description of the work, which will “focus..on the geography of labour and social reproduction.” My guess is that this is from the early-1990s as it say you hope to publish all series titles by mid-1993 at the latest.

did.unittitle: Women and Industrial Change Book Prospectus

scopecontent.p: An outline for a book entitled: 'Women's Role in Economic Transformation: The Contradiction of Female Wage Labor' accompanied by some notes and a copy of a 3-page proposal abstract from when SMC worked at the U.S.-Mexico Study Center. This folder was in with the other folders in the 'Reshaping U Geography Book with Linda ' hanging folder.

An unpublished paper, written with Margaret Fitzsimmons (then at UCLA), entitled 'Women in Geography: Limits to Progress,' that was submitted to The Professional Geographer in November, 1989, and some related pieces.
Contains presentation notes, a full script, and overheads for talks relating to SMC 1993 paper 'Market Rules'

Notes and executive summary for a talk entitled 'Filling the Growing Need for Childcare and Elderly Care' that was given at the Department of Labor, as well as the synopsis for a related talk given at an OECD conference in Paris in December of the same year.

did.unittitle: Child and Elderly Care OECD Tables and Graphs to Make

scopecontent.p: Materials supporting an OECD report (SMC, 1997, Childcare and Elderly Care: What Opportunities for Women?) and talks (in R 4-28) along with a cover letter to the OECD.

Figures (paper and overhead) and notes for a lecture on new urban forms. It is not clear if this is a class lecture or not, although the files was in with other, more academic, material. Also notable is a generic letter from the Project Director of the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment, that came along with a report. The letter, dated October 1995, is of particular interest because it acknowledges that the office is being shut down.
Contains paper and correspondence relating to a workshop in Jordan to discuss "Jordan's Policies and Strategies in Audiovisual Media" and the industries that produce them.
Drafts and correspondence relating to the study of Jordan's media industry
Materials relating to "The Fortress City: Privatized Spaces, Consumer Citizenship" a chapter in Ash Amin's edited book, Post-Fordism, including responses to queries on a text

Materials and correspondence around the remaking of a faulty table that was schedued to be included SMC's book chapter "The Production of Consumption" appearing in Wrigley and Lowe's edited volume Retailing, Consumption and Capital.
Typescript of the "Double Jeopardy" paper about rural women published through the Southwest Institute for Research on Women
Materials related to regional differences in contingent labor. Many of the notes are have a heading that indicates they are for the "Buffalo Paper"
A reading and notes related to quesitons of contingency. Four pages of handwritten notes are titled 'For critique of neoclassical approach to the problem.' Two pages are notes from an OECD study.
Handwritten notes on contingency
Materials, including notes, relating to the idea of corporate behavior in peak times and slack times
Bibliographical materials, including notes, relating to the issue of contingent labor
